div.note: This same Padre Cristoforo stood still on the doorstep. With one look at the women, he realized that his forebodings had not been wrong.
With the inquiring tone that anticipates bad news, while lifting his beard with a slight tilt of his head, he asked, “What is it, child?”
Lucia’s reply was to burst into tears.
Her mother started to apologize for having been so bold as to…but the friar came forward. Sitting down on the three-legged stool, he waved away all formalities, saying to Lucia, “Be calm, poor girl.”
And to Agnese, “Tell me what happened.”
As the good woman told the sad tale as best she could, the priest turned a thousand different colors, one moment lifting his eyes to the heavens, the other tapping his feet.
Once the story had ended, he covered his face with his hands and exclaimed, “Lord have mercy!
For how long…” Without finishing his sentence, he turned to the women again. “You poor things,” he said, “God is testing you.
Poor Lucia!”
“You won’t abandon us, Father?” she sobbed.
“Abandon you?” he replied.
“If I did, then how could I find the courage to ask God for anything for myself? You, in this condition? You, whom God has placed in my care?
Don’t lose heart. He will come to your aid. He sees everything. He can use even a nobody like me to humble a…Come, let’s see what we can do.”
At this, he placed his left elbow on his knee and rested his forehead on the palm of his hand. With his right hand he cupped his beard and his chin, as if to keep a firm grip on his every impulse.
But the more he thought about it, the more he realized how urgent and complicated the case was, and how uncertain and perilous the solutions.
“Make Don Abbondio feel ashamed, and show him that he has failed in his duties?
But shame and duty mean nothing to him if he’s afraid.
Frighten him?
The only thing he’s afraid of is a gun.
Inform the Cardinal-Archbishop of everything and invoke his authority?
That would take time. And meanwhile? And then?
Even if the girl were to get married, would that stop this man?
Who knows how far he would go?…Resist him?
But how?
“Ah,” thought the priest in anguish, “if I could only get the brothers from here and Milan to help me!
But this matter doesn’t involve the whole community. They’d leave me on my own.
He acts like he’s a friend to the monastery, passing himself off as a supporter of the Capuchins. And his bravi have sought sanctuary with us more than once.
I’d be on my own. They’d accuse me of being a hothead, a liar, a troublemaker. What’s more, if I act at the wrong time, I could make things worse for the poor girl.”

Weighing the pros and cons of this side or that, he thought it best to confront Don Rodrigo himself and try to dissuade him from his sinister designs, through pleading, fear of the afterlife, and fear of this life, too, if possible.
At worst, he would see more clearly just how set the man was on his evil pursuit, learn more about his intentions, and come away the wiser for it.

As Padre Cristoforo turned things over in his mind, Renzo, who, understandably, couldn’t keep away from the cottage, appeared at the door. Seeing the priest absorbed in thought, and the women signaling not to disturb him, he stood there in silence.
Looking up to tell the women his plan, the priest noticed Renzo and greeted him with a familiar affection made more intense by compassion.
“Did they tell you…Padre?” asked Renzo in a pained voice.
“Unfortunately. That is why I’m here.”
“What do you have to say about that scoundrel?” “What does it matter?
He’s not here to listen. What good would my words do?
What I want to tell you, dear Renzo, is to place your faith in God, for He will not abandon you.”
“Bless you for those words!” exclaimed the youth.
“You’re not one of those who always blames the poor!
But the pastor, and that lawyer of lost causes…”
“Dwelling on it will only upset you needlessly.
I’m just a poor friar, but I’ll repeat what I just told the women. For what little I can do, I will not abandon you.”
“You’re not like my friends of the world!
They’re all talk!
You should have heard the promises they used to make in the good old days.
They said they’d shed blood for me. They’d defend me against the devil himself.
If I had an enemy…all I had to do was give the signal, and he’d be eating his words.
Now they can’t run away from me fast enough.”
Looking up, he noticed that the friar’s face had clouded over and realized, too late, that some things were better left unsaid.
Hoping to take back his words, he started hemming and hawing. “What I was trying to say…what I meant…you see, I was trying to say…”
“What were you trying to say?
Tell me! Here you were, ready to ruin my work even before I’d begun!
It’s a good thing we stopped you in time.
You placed your faith in your friends?…What friends!…They couldn’t have helped you if they had wanted to!
And you were trying to lose the one friend who can and will help you!
Don’t you realize that God is the friend of the afflicted who place their faith in him?
Don’t you know that the weak can never win by showing their teeth?

Even if…” He grabbed Renzo’s arm. His face, without any loss of authority, took on a look of solemn remorse. His eyes were lowered, his voice, slow and cavernous. “Even if…it comes at a terrible price!
Renzo! Will you place your trust in me?…In me, a mere mortal, an insignificant friar?
Will you place your trust in God?”
“Yes, I will,” answered Renzo, “He is the true Lord.”
“So promise me you won’t confront or provoke anyone, and let me handle this.”
“I promise.”
Lucia let out a deep breath, as if a burden had been lifted, and Agnese said, “There’s a good boy.”
“Listen, my children,” Padre Cristoforo continued, “I’ll go and have a talk with this man today.
If God touches his heart and lends power to my words, fine. If not, He’ll help us find another solution.
In the meantime, I want you to stay here. Keep to yourselves, remain indoors, avoid gossip, and stay out of sight.
I’ll be back this evening or, at the latest, tomorrow.”
At this he cut short all the thank-yous and bless yous and left.
He headed for the monastery, arriving in time to go to the choir and sing the midday offices, have lunch, and set out immediately on the road to the lair of the beast he was seeking to tame.
— The palace of Don Rodrigo rose, isolated and severe, like a fortress atop one of the hills scattered along and rising above the lakeshore.
The anonymous author (who should have simply told us the name of the place) indicates that it was located about three miles uphill from the young couple’s village and four miles from the monastery.
At the foot of the hill, on the south side facing the lake, there was a cluster of huts inhabited by Don Rodrigo’s peasants, like the miniature capital of his miniature kingdom.
A passing glance was enough to grasp the livelihoods and conditions of the villagers.
Through the occasional open door a quick look at the ground-floor rooms was greeted by a jumble of rifles, muskets, hoes, rakes, straw hats, hairnets, and powder horns hanging from the wall.

The people lingering about were brawny, gruff ruffians with big forelocks tucked into a hairnet worn behind their heads. Toothless old men who, at the least provocation, were ready to gnash their gums. Women with mannish faces and muscular arms that served to aid the tongue whenever words failed. Even the expressions and movements of the children playing in the street implied something insolent and provocative.
Fra Cristoforo crossed the village, ascended a winding path, and came to a small clearing in front of the palace.
The door was closed, a sign that the master was dining and did not wish to be disturbed.

Although the few small windows facing the street were covered by rotting and dilapidated shutters, they were fortified by thick iron bars. The ground-floor windows were so high up that a man standing on another’s shoulders could barely reach the windowsill.

A heavy silence reigned, and a passerby might have thought the house was abandoned were it not for four creatures, two living and two dead, located symmetrically, outside, indicating that the place was inhabited.

Two large vultures, wings spread wide and heads dangling—one already plucked and rotting in the open air, the other still whole and feathered—were nailed to either side of the door. Two bravi were lying on benches to the right and the left, standing guard and waiting to be called in to enjoy leftovers from the master’s table.

The friar stopped in his tracks, as if he was prepared to wait. But one of the bravi stood up and said, “Padre, please, go on ahead. We do not keep Capuchins waiting here. We’re friends of the monastery. There have been times in my life when I was in a tight spot. If the monastery had closed the door on me, I’d have been done for.”
At this he banged the door knocker twice.

The sound was greeted from inside by the baying and yelping of mastiffs and puppies. A few seconds later an elderly servant arrived, grumbling. As soon as he saw the priest, however, he made a deep bow. He shushed the animals with his gestures and his voice, ushered him into a narrow courtyard, and closed the door behind them.
He then accompanied him to a reception room, and, looking at him with an air of surprise and respect, said, “Aren’t you…Padre Cristoforo of Pescarenico?”
“One and the same.”
“You…here?”
“As you can see, my good man.”
“You’re here to do good, no doubt.
To do good,” he continued, muttering to himself and setting off again, “we could all use some good.”
After crossing two or three other unlit rooms, they reached the doorway to the dining room.
There was a loud clatter of forks and knives, glasses and plates, and of discordant voices trying to talk over one another.
The friar wanted to stay back, and was arguing with the servant from behind the door to let him wait in a corner of the house until dinner was over, when the door suddenly opened.

A certain Count Attilio (a cousin of the master, whom I have already mentioned, though not by name) was seated directly across from him. Seeing a shaven head and a tunic, and noticing the good friar’s attempts at modesty, he called out, “Wait, wait. Don’t run away, reverend Father. Come in. Come in.”
Don Rodrigo, without guessing the exact reason for the visit, still had an inkling of its purpose and would gladly have forgone it.
But since the carefree Attilio had been so loud, there was no turning back. So he, too, said, “Come in, Padre, come in.”
The friar came forward, bowed to the master of the house, and gestured with both hands in response to the salutations of the other guests.
When an honest man confronts an evildoer, many but not all of us like to imagine the former with his head held high, a steady gaze, chest out, and tongue untied.
In reality, however, such a posture requires a variety of circumstances that rarely coincide.

So you shouldn’t be surprised that Fra Cristoforo—with his clear conscience, firm belief in the rightness of his cause, and mixed feelings of both repugnance and pity for Don Rodrigo—stood before him with an air of intimidation and deference. There sat Don Rodrigo, at the head of the table, in his own home, his own domain, surrounded by friends, flattery, and many signs of his power, with a look on his face that would squelch any request—not to mention advice, correction, or rebuke—before it could be uttered.
To his right was Count Attilio, his cousin and, needless to say, his partner in debauchery and brutality, who had come up from Milan for a few days in the country.

To his left, on the opposite side of the table, sat the Mayor, whose deference was tempered by a smug, superior attitude, the same man who in theory should have been demanding justice for Renzo Tramaglino, and making Don Rodrigo obey the laws we have read earlier.

Facing the Mayor, with a demeanor of the purest, most abject deference, was our lawyer, Professor Argle-Bargle, in a black cloak, his nose even redder than usual. Opposite the two cousins were two anonymous guests. The only thing our manuscript says about them is that all they did was eat, nod their heads, laugh, and agree with everything one guest might say that was not contradicted by another.
“Give the padre a seat,” Don Rodrigo ordered.
A servant appeared with a chair, on which Padre Cristoforo sat, while making his apologies for having come at such an inopportune time.
“I would much rather speak with you alone, at your convenience, on an important matter,” he whispered to Don Rodrigo in a soft voice.
“Fine, fine, we’ll talk,” the man answered, “but in the meantime bring the padre something to drink.”

The priest tried to decline, but Don Rodrigo, raising his voice above the rising din, bellowed, “No, by God, you won’t do me this discourtesy. Let it never be said that a Capuchin left this house without tasting my wine, nor an insolent creditor without a switch from my forest.”
His words sparked general laughter, and briefly interrupted a heated argument among the guests.

A servant carrying a tray with a small flask of wine and a long-stemmed glass presented it to the friar. Not wishing to refuse such a pressing invitation from the man whose favor he hoped to gain, he poured himself a glass without making a fuss and started to sip it slowly.

“You’ll have to do better than quote Tasso, Reverend Mayor. He argues the opposite of what you’re saying.” Count Attilio began shouting again. “That erudite poet, that great man, knew chivalry inside out. That’s why before Argante’s messenger delivered his challenge to the Christian knights, he had him request permission from the pious Godfrey of Bouillon to…”

“But that,” replied the Mayor, just as vociferously, “was superfluous, a poetic flourish, since by his nature and by the law of nations, jure gentium, the messenger cannot be touched. Not to mention the old proverb, ‘Don’t shoot the messenger.’
And proverbs, my dear count, contain the wisdom of the human race.
And since the messenger said nothing on his own behalf, but only presented a written challenge…”
“When are you going to get it through your head that the messenger was an insolent fool, who didn’t know the first thing about…”
“With your permission, gentlemen,” Don Rodrigo broke in, not wanting the argument to get out of hand, “let’s put the question to Padre Cristoforo, and let him be the judge.”

“Fine with me,” said Count Attilio, who agreed that having a Capuchin rule on a question of chivalry was the most diplomatic solution. The Mayor, who was more riled up by the argument, struggled to keep quiet, and made a face as if to say, “Don’t be ridiculous.”
“Well, if I’ve understood correctly,” the priest began, “I’m hardly an expert in these matters.”
“Your professions of modesty don’t fool me,” said Don Rodrigo. “Come now.
We all know you weren’t born with the cowl over your head. You used to be a man of the world yourself.
Let’s get on with it. Here is the question.”
“The fact of the matter…” Count Attilio tried to talk over him.
“Let me tell the story, cousin,” Don Rodrigo cut in, “since I’m the impartial one.

A Spanish knight sends a challenge to a Milanese knight. His messenger, finding that the knight isn’t home, delivers the challenge to the man’s brother, who reads it, and, by way of a reply, gives the messenger a few whacks with a stick.
At issue here…”
“Well done and well deserved!” cried Count Attilio.
“His reply was truly inspired!”
“Like hell it was,” chimed in the Mayor.
“Beating a messenger! It’s sacrilegious!
I’m sure you’ll agree, Padre, that a true knight would never do such a thing.”
“Yes, he would!” shouted the Count, “Take it from me. If anyone knows the rules of chivalry it’s me.
Now if he’d used his fists, it would have been another matter. But a stick doesn’t get your hands dirty.
What I can’t understand is why you care so much about the skin of a lowborn messenger?”
“Who said anything about his skin, my dear Count?
You’re putting words in my mouth.
I was talking about his person, not his back.
My main concern is the jure gentium.

Tell me, please, whether the fetials—the priestly diplomats whom the ancient Romans sent to issue their challenges—requested permission to deliver a message? Can you name a single writer who mentions the beating of a fetial?”
“What have the ancient Romans got to do with anything? They were very casual, and in matters of this sort, they were backward, very backward.

But according to the rules of modern chivalry—the only true chivalry—I say and I argue that a messenger who dares to hand a gentleman a challenge without first requesting permission is insolent, wrong, doubly-wrong, and punishable, doubly-punishable…”
“See if you can answer this syllogism.”
“No, no, no.”
“Yes, yes, yes.
To strike an unarmed man is treachery. Atqui he’s a messenger de quo unarmed, ergo…”
“Wait a minute, Signor Mayor.”
“What do you mean, wait?” “I mean wait.
Listen to yourself. You say it’s treachery to stab or shoot someone in the back. There are other instances that I could mention, too…but let’s stick to the question.
I’ll grant you that such acts are generally considered treacherous. But to smack a lowlife a few times?
It’d be nice to tell him first, ‘Now I’m going to beat you,’ as if you were saying, ‘En garde!’ to a gentleman.
And you, esteemed counselor, rather than giggling your agreement, why not use your honeyed tongue to help me persuade this gentleman?” “Me?”
Professor Argle-Bargle stammered. “I was just enjoying this erudite dispute, and I thank the lucky stars that gave rise to such a gracious war of wits.
But it’s not for me to pass sentence. Your most honorable self has already designated a judge…the padre…”
“True,” said Don Rodrigo, “but how can you expect the judge to speak when the litigants refuse to shut up!”
“Not another word from me,” said the Count.
The Mayor sealed his lips and raised his hand in a gesture of resignation.
“Thank heaven for small favors!
Please proceed, Padre,” said Don Rodrigo with mock solemnity.
“I’ve already made my excuses. As I said, I’m no expert,” replied Fra Cristoforo, returning his glass to a servant.
“That’s a poor excuse,” the two cousins piped up, “we await your sentence.”
“In that case,” the friar continued, “in my humble opinion, there should be no challenges, no messengers, and no beatings.”
The guests looked at one another in disbelief.
“That’s rich,” said Count Attilio.
“Forgive me, Padre, but you couldn’t be more wrong.
You obviously don’t know the ways of the world.”
“Him?” said Don Rodrigo. “Didn’t you hear what I said before, dear Cousin? He knows the world as well as you or I. Admit it, Padre, you’ve sown your wild oats, haven’t you?”

Rather than rise to this loving question, the friar had a private word with himself: “They’re trying to get under your skin. But remember, you’re not here for your own sake. Ignore anything directed only at you.”
“That may well be,” said the cousin, “but the friar…what did you say his name is?”
“Padre Cristoforo,” a chorus of voices replied.
“But Padre Cristoforo, most revered lord, you’d turn the world upside down with your maxims.
No challenges!
No beatings!
No questions of honor? Impunity for every lowlife?
Luckily what you propose is impossible.”
“Your turn, Counselor,” exclaimed Don Rodrigo, hoping to steer the dispute away from the first two contenders. “Your turn. We can always count on you to take both sides.
Let’s see you take Fra Cristoforo’s defense!”

“To be honest,” Argle-Bargle replied, brandishing his fork in the air and addressing the priest, “I can’t understand how Padre Cristoforo, who is both the perfect friar and the perfect man of the world, didn’t realize that his sentence, which from the pulpit might sound fine, excellent, and fair, is without merit—I say this with all due respect—in a dispute about chivalry.
But he knows better than I that to everything there is a season. And this time, I think, he was pulling our leg to avoid having to pass sentence.”
How does one respond to arguments based on wisdom so ancient yet so new? By saying nothing.
Which is exactly what our friar did.
But Don Rodrigo, to cut the discussion short, introduced another subject.
“By the way,” he said, “I’ve heard that in Milan there are rumors of a peace treaty.”

The reader will know that in those years a war was being waged over the succession to the Duchy of Mantua, which upon the death of Vincenzo Gonzaga, who had left no legitimate heir, came into the possession of his next of kin, the Duke of Nevers.

Louis XIII of France, or rather his chief minister, Cardinal Richelieu, supported Nevers, a naturalized Frenchman who was very devoted to the French King. Philip IV of Spain, or rather his prime minister, the Count of Olivares (commonly known as the Count-Duke), did not want him in Mantua for the same reason, and declared war on Nevers.

And since Mantua was an imperial fief, the two parties pressured the emperor, Ferdinand II, through negotiations, petitions, and threats: the Cardinal, for the emperor to grant investiture to the new duke; the Count-Duke, for him to deny it, and indeed to help drive Nevers from Italy.
“I’m inclined to believe,” Count Attilio went on, “that we may indeed be close to a peace treaty.
I’ve heard reports…”
“Don’t believe everything you hear,” the Mayor interrupted.

“Even in this pocket of the world, I’m in a position to know what’s happening. The Spanish commander of the Fort, who out of the goodness of his heart seems to like me, is the son of one of the Count-Duke’s protégés, so he knows everything that is going on…”
“Every day in Milan I just happen to rub shoulders with some very important people. And I have it on good authority that the Pope, who is very interested in keeping the peace, has proposed…”
“As well he should. Everything in its place. His Holiness is doing his duty. A pope should always act as a mediator between Christian princes. But the Count-Duke has his policy, and…”
“And, and, and. Do you have any idea, my dear sir, what the emperor is thinking at this moment?
Do you really believe that Mantua is the only place on earth? He has many other things on his mind.
Do you have any idea, for instance, whether the Emperor can trust his prince of Valdistano or Vallistai, or whatever his name is, and whether…”
“The correct pronunciation in the German language,” the Mayor interrupted, once again, “is Vagliensteino, as I have heard it pronounced many times by the Spanish commander.
But rest assured that…”
“You would teach me?” the Count retorted, but Don Rodrigo gave him a look as if to intimate that, for his sake, he should stop arguing.
The Count fell silent and the Mayor, like a ship broken free from a sandbank, continued full sail down his loquacious stream.
“Vagliensteino doesn’t worry me, since the Count-Duke is keeping an eye on everyone and everything. And if he does get out of hand, the Count-Duke will set him straight, by fair means or foul.

He has his eyes everywhere, I tell you, and his arm is long. If he has determined, great statesman that he is, that the Duke of Nevers will not cement his claim on Mantua, then you can bet he won’t. And Cardinal Riciliù will fall flat on his face.
What a laugh, for the Cardinal to think that he can get the better of a man like the Count-Duke of Olivares.
Honestly, I’d love to be reborn two-hundred years from now to hear what posterity has to say about his claims.
It’s not enough to want it. You have to have brains. And no one in the world has the brains of the Count-Duke.

The Count-Duke, with all due respect,” the Mayor continued, the wind still in his sails and amazed to find nary an obstacle in sight, “is an old fox, who can hide his tracks from anyone. When he nods to the right, you can be sure he’ll go left. No one can ever claim that they know his plans. Not even those who execute them, who have to write the reports.
I know what I’m talking about, because my good friend the commander is so kind as to confide in me.

On the other hand, the Count-Duke knows exactly what’s cooking in the kettles of all the other courts. And no sooner have all those big-shot statesmen (there are plenty of sly ones, you have to admit) come up with a plan than the Count-Duke has it already figured out, with that big brain of his, with those secret ways of his, with those tentacles everywhere.
Poor Cardinal Riciliù, no matter how hard he tries—sniffing around, sweating, plotting—every time he sets an ambush, he ends up getting ambushed himself by the Count-Duke.”

Heaven knows when the Mayor would have made landfall if Don Rodrigo, prompted also by the look on his cousin’s face, hadn’t turned to a servant as if he had received a sudden inspiration and gestured that he should bring up a bottle of his best vintage.
“Mayor, gentlemen,” he said, “a toast to the Count-Duke! I’ll let you be the judge of whether the wine is worthy of the man.”
The Mayor replied with a bow, expressing his special appreciation, since he considered everything done or said in honor of the Count-Duke to be a tribute, in part, to himself.
“Long live Don Gaspar de Guzmán, Count of Olivares, Duke of San Lúcar, great privado of King Philip the Great, our ruler!” he exclaimed, raising his glass.
Privado, for those of you who don’t know, was the term used in those days to indicate a royal favorite.
“May he live a thousand years!” everyone replied.
“Pour a glass for the padre,” Don Rodrigo commanded.
“I’m so sorry,” the friar replied, “but I’ve already made one exception to the rules, I couldn’t possibly…”
“What!” demanded Don Rodrigo, “you would refuse to toast to the Count-Duke?
Does this mean you are siding with the Navarrese?”
Navarrese was the term then used to disparage the French, taken from the princes of Navarre, who began to rule the country after Henry IV ascended to the throne.
In the face of such an exhortation, it is better to drink.
All the diners sang out their exclamations, and their praises of the wine, except Professor Argle-Bargle, whose raised head, glazed eyes, and tight lips expressed far more than words ever could.
“What do you have to say, eh, counselor?” Don Rodrigo asked.

Extracting from his glass a nose that was redder and shinier than the wine, Professor Argle-Bargle gave his answer, syllable by syllable. “I say, I pronounce, and I hereby sentence that this is the Olivares of wines—Censui, et in eam ivi sententiam—and that its equal cannot be found in all twenty-two kingdoms of our King, God bless him. I hereby declare and determine that the dinners of our illustrious Lord Don Rodrigo surpass the banquets of Heliogabalus, and that the famine is hereby banished and banned in perpetuity from this palace, where splendor resides and reigns.”
“Hear hear,” they all shouted as one. But that word which the counselor had uttered so casually, famine, suddenly placed the grim subject at the center of everyone’s thoughts.
On this they all agreed, at least in principle, but the noise they made was almost louder than if they hadn’t. Everyone was suddenly speaking at the same time.
“There is no famine!” said one. “It’s the hoarders…”
“And the bakers,” said another, “hiding the wheat.
String ’em up!”
“That’s right. String ’em up, without mercy!”
“After fair trials!” shouted the Mayor.
“Trials?” Count Attilio shouted even louder. “No. Summary justice.
Grab three, four, five, or six—the richest and the greediest—and string ’em up.” “Make an example of them.
Without examples nothing will change.”
“String ’em up, and grain’ll come pouring out of every corner.”

Who among you, in passing by a country fair, has not laughed to hear the harmonizing of a company of troubadours, when, between songs, they tune their instruments. Each makes his instrument screech as loud as he can, the better to hear it above the racket of the others. So you can imagine the cacophony of those speeches, if we can call them that.

Meanwhile the wine flowed freely, and its praises were sung, and rightly so, intermingled with opinions on economic justice. The words heard most sonorously and frequently were “nectar of the gods” and “string ’em up.”

Don Rodrigo meanwhile was staring at the only person who remained quiet. He saw the friar sitting there motionless, giving no sign of impatience or haste, no attempt to remind his host that he was waiting, but looking as if he had no intention of leaving until he had said his piece.
Don Rodrigo would have gladly forgone that conversation, but to take leave of a Capuchin without first hearing him out was not in keeping with his policies.

Since the nuisance could not be avoided, he resolved to address it immediately and be done with it. He rose from the table, and the whole red-faced brigade stood with him, without ceasing their racket.
Asking leave of his guests, he rather stiffly approached the friar, who had stood up immediately along with the others. And saying, “I am at your service,” Don Rodrigo led him to another room.
